The Partion appears to be damaged because it's showing your sdb drive is fragmented up to 20. There shouldn't be any fragments at all. >>1296378
>It's called uptalk
No, that's something different.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_rising_terminal

OP asked an "elided question", a question where the actual question clause is elided, to be assumed from context. That's not the same thing as "uptalk", which is a statement that doesn't ask any question, but is spoken as if it did. Key word here is "spoken".

Examples of elided questions:
>Reinstalling the drivers doesn't fix it?
>Reinstalling the drivers doesn't fix it[, so what should I try next]?

>requesting newer fps games recommendations without woke garbage?
>requesting newer fps games recommendations without woke garbage[; which games meet these criteria]?

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg

posts.sub: burning a DVD to be played on a DVD player
posts.com:
i posted here about getting a download of Chinese knockoff cars movie a few days back. My request was solved, and someone found me a download. I downloaded it in mp4 format, but my research told me that a DVD player won't accept that. I then converted that mp4 file into a m4v file.

Is m4v an acceptable file to burn on to a DVD to played on a DVD player?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1298027
>Is m4v an acceptable file to burn on to a DVD to played on a DVD player?
No.
You need to google "DVD authoring", video DVDs are not data DVDs with video files on, they're an entirely different thing. They appear to have a filesystem and a VIDEO_TS directory, but that's just so computers can read them without you having to be administrator. The actual layout of the tracks and the video frames on the disk is super important, you can't just write a random data disk with the files in VIDEO_TS, because DVD players don't actually read the filesystem at all.

There's also very specific codecs, resolutions and bitrates you have to use, or the DVD player won't read it right.

Most DVD authoring programs though, you can just drop a m4v onto them and they will transcode it into MPEG2 and generate a correctly-formed ISO automatically with the default settings.m

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1298027
>i posted here about getting a download of Chinese knockoff cars
hope you thanked the guys who helped but otherwise no one cares.

>mp4 format, but my research told me that a DVD player won't accept that

Your research should also have told you that DVD-Video is MP1 or MP2 only. The MP4 format would be converted into MP2 when you authored the DVD.

>I then converted that mp4 file into a m4v file.

You've wasted your time. M4V is just MP4 with a different file extension where V is for video since MP4 is a standard for audio and video streams.

Some DVD players will also read data discs and playback different file types of disc types like mkv, mp4, wav, mp3, SVCD, etc. If you player does that then it doesn't matter what you do, just burn the file to disc.

But if you need an actual DVD-Video disc, like the sort of thing you used to rent from the video shop, then you need to use DVD authoring software to create the DVD files since DVD-Video isn't just a video file, it's manager files, a title set, IFO files, programme chain

The DVD authroing progam will solve that for you but you need to find one.

>>1297622
Beast Tamer will finish tomorrow and aside from one bathing scene it's very tame, I have no qualms saying it's the best anime of the year. Dunbine if you don't mind a lot of 80s cheese although the ending segment has a naked fairy on it (just prancing, nothing sexual). I will second >>1298406 on Escaflowne, but definitely not Rayearth (painfully meh) or Now and Then Here and There (legit horrible). Orguss is a very loosely defined isekai, not the medieval type, but if you don't mind the sex scene in the beginning of the first episode (which does become a major plot point, it has a purpose) it's definitely worth watching. Knights and Magic isn't anything fantastic, but is pretty comfy and the main hero is a favorite on /m/. The 2006 remake of Gaiking is similar to Jules Verne stuff, just more high tech. I want to recommend Granzort, but the fansubs on that stopped right during the last quarter so if you want to finish it you'll have to read crabsticks (what /m/ calls poorly translated bootleg subs, usually of Hong Kong origin), if for no other reason watch that one for the kick ass opening theme.

>The monogatari series
I like it.
Visually interesting, most of it is dialog and banter, so a very character-focused show.

>World trigger
I like it.
Plotwise it's just another retarded shounen, but it has many "tournament arcs" and the battles are always very nice, all the strategies used are fun and no victory feels like a cheat win. Do you remember Shikamaru in Naruto? It's like all fights are like his.
Get ready to skip a 3 minute episode recap every episode and an entire filler arc by the end of first season, cause it's UNWATCHABLE, I regret heavily trying to stomach it.
I should add I like all the girls designs (except one), and there are MANY. That's very rare for me in any show I watch.

>Samurai champloo
I like it.
Packed with action and stylish animation, if you like "anime for grownups" like Cowboy Bebop, you won't regret it.

The rest I haven't seen.

posts.com:
The topic is ratio and proportions. I'm unable to find the proportion required to solve this exercise.

A rectangle of area A mm^2 is divided into two parts in the ratio p:q. Find expressions for their areas.

The solutions are pA/(p+q) and qA/(p+g). But how do I get there from just knowing p:q and p+q=A?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1298212
For starters, if you add those two solutions you get A.
If I have 5 bucks and you have 2 bucks, what portion of the total money do I have? What portion do you have? I have 5/(5+2)=5/7, while you have 2/(5+2)=2/7. It's the same idea, except you replace 5 and 2 with p and q. Now, these are just the ratios, boyo. To get the area, you gotta multiply the ratio by the area. If you learned any physics, you'd know the units of an equation must match on both sides of the equation. A is of mm^2 units, while p, q and p/(p+q) or q/(p+q) are unitless (pure numbers). As such, p+q≠A, since p and q are just numbers while A is an area.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1298215
Thanks. I now get where p/(p+q) and q/(p+g) come frome. But how are you supposed to figure out to multiply them by A? I thought the task was to come up with a proportion that can be solved for the solutions, but can't come up with anything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1298310
p and q are numbers, unitless
A has a unit

posts.com: I've been thinking about the industrial revolution and watching isekais like the loser I am and was wanting to get a bunch of info graphs or blueprints of machines that made the industrial revolution possible but I can't find how the first metal steam powered lathes were made. Anyone have shit on stuff like that? Steam engines lathes and other machinery from scratch and how to make it basically.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1298201
>first metal steam powered lathes were made.
They weren't, which is why you can't find them.
Mills used to use waterwheels, which drove an overhead axle that ran the length of the building and powered every machine in it (which were all laid out in a line and roughly the same orientation).
Later, the waterwheel was replaced with a steam engine or electric motor, but the driveshafts remained. It wasn't until much later that electricity and electric motors were affordable and convenient enough to integrate into the machines; steam engines never got there. If you needed to run one machine, you'd park your steam tractor outside and run a drivebelt in through the wall.

>>1298079
You can add an image to the file using ffmpeg:
ffmpeg -i music.m4a -i image.jpg -c copy -disposition:v:0 attached-pic music-with-image.m4a
You can do this for all files with powershell:
Get-ChildItem *.m4a | ${ffmpeg -i "$($_.basename).m4a" -i "$($_.basename).jpg" -c copy -disposition:v:0 attached_pic "new/$($_.Name)"}
This puts the new files in a directory "new". You can also overwrite them by making the output name the same as the input and adding the "-y" option to ffmpeg.

I have a long metal fence around my home near the sidewalk. There's a small concrete planter outside as decoration (it has some aloe and stuff). The thing is, there's this neighbour who every night lets his dog out, to pee outside, and it seems to like to pee on my planter for some reason, it doesn't always pee there, but it has been 2 times I noticed (because the sidewalk is not water absorbent, so the big smelly stain stays there). I'm not from the US, so we don't have this "we can sue you for doing that shit in my property" laws, so the most I can do is ask him to stop, but it's always whenever I'm sleeping, so I just noticed when that happens to other houses (the dog pees over the neighbors cars if they are outside).
Now my question is...
Is there a way to make the thing not want to pee over my property? like... some chemical substance (if it doesn't damage plants, better). It was a pain in the ass to clean that pee and remove the smell (I also might be getting paranoid so maybe it's some stray who did it, but stray dogs are a rare sigh in here).

pic semi related, that's how the dog looks (it's a small breed I guess)
